revision.text:
'''Marie McDonald''' (July 6, 1923-October 21, 1965) was an [[United States|American]] singer and actor. She was in many [[movie]]s and [[television program]]s.
McDonald was born in [[Kentucky]]. She died from an overdose of drugs at age 32 in [[California]].
{{us-bio-stub}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:McDonald, Marie}} [[Category:American movie actors]] [[Category:Singers from Kentucky]] [[Category:Actors from Kentucky]] [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:1965 deaths]]

revision.text: '''Laurie Bird''' (born September 26 1953-died June 15 1979) was an [[United States|American]] actress and photogragher who had only three movies. Her most notable was the 1977 movie ''Annie Hall''. She died by Valium overdose in [[New York City]] at age 25. {{us-bio-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bird, Laurie}} [[Category:People from New York]] [[Category:American movie actors]] [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:1979 deaths]]

revision.text:
'''Leslie Phillips''' [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] (born 20 April 1924) is a [[British people|British]] [[actor]]. He was born in [[Tottenham]], [[London]] and moved to [[Chingford]] when he was nine.<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/interview-leslie-phillips-oh-leslie-you-really-are-a-gorgeous-beast-1289756.html Indy interview]</ref>
== References == <references/>
== Other websites == *{{imdb|0680587}}

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Non-profit organizations]]; added [[Category:Non-profit organizations of France]] using [[Help:Gadget-HotCat|HotCat]]
revision.text:
<!-- EDIT BELOW THIS LINE --> {{Infobox university |image = |name = ENAC Alumni |motto = Association des anciens élèves de l'École Nationale de l'Aviation Civile |mottoeng = Alumni association of the French Civil Aviation University |image_name = |image_size = |caption = | colours = Blue and Grey {{color box|Blue}}{{color box|Grey}} |established = 1987 |type = [[Organization|Nonprofit]] |president = Anne Cotel-Ballot |city = [[Toulouse]] |state = [[Midi-Pyrénées]] |country = [[France]] |website = [http://www.alumni.enac.fr alumni.enac.fr] }}
'''ENAC Alumni''' (also referred to as '''INGENAC''')<ref>{{fr}} [http://www.pinkfloydrugby.fr/last/index.php/17-pink-floyd-enac-alumni Les Pink Floyds dans la Newsletter ENAC Alumni]</ref> is an [[alumni]] [[association]] based in [[Toulouse]], [[Midi-Pyrénées]]. It was started by Robert Aladenyse,<ref>{{fr}} [http://www.alumni.enac.fr/docs/2012133038_20121105-aladenyse-plaquette.pdf Robert Aladenyse: le bon génie]</ref> in 1987.<ref>{{fr}}Book ''50 ans d'Enac au service de l'aviation'', A. Gilotte, J.P Husson, C.Lazerge</ref> The main mission of the association is to gather the alumnus of the [[French Civil Aviation University]]. In 2013, it has almost 20,000 members.<ref>{{fr}} [http://www.aerobuzz.fr/spip.php?breve1649 Le nouveau site des anciens de l’ENAC en ligne]</ref> It is a [[non-profit organization]].
== History ==
When the [[French Civil Aviation University]] was created in 1949, its first goal was to train people of the [[Directorate General for Civil Aviation]]. At the beginning of the 1970s, the university started to train professionals for the [[aerospace engineering]] industry. Robert Aladenyse (1931-2003, graduated in 1964) decided in 1987 to create a non-profit organization for alumnus called INGENAC. In the 2000s, the development in France of [[Master's degree]] and ''[[Mastère Spécialisé|Mastères Spécialisés]]'' courses encouraged the association to support and represent these new alumnus.<ref>{{fr}} [http://www.lifacolor.com/images/works/print/ingenac/print-ingenac-annuaire.jpg Annuaire ingénieurs diplômés et mastères]</ref>
On 1 Janunary 2010, [[French Civil Aviation University|ENAC]] became the biggest aeronautical university in [[Europe]].<ref>[http://aviationreport.blogspot.fr/2011/01/france-hosts-largest-european.html France hosts the largest European university for Civil Aviation : ENAC]</ref><ref>[http://archive.is/Ugc3 French ENAC SEFA merge to become biggest Civil Aviation University in Europe]</ref> Because of this, INGENAC decided to rename itself ENAC Alumni and gather graduates of all the degrees of the [[French Civil Aviation University]] (including the ''[[Technicien aéronautique d'exploitation|Techniciens aéronautique d'exploitation]]'', the ''[[Technicien supérieur de l'aviation|Techniciens supérieur de l'aviation]]'', the [[Air Traffic Safety Electronics Personnel|Air Traffic Safety Electronics Personnels]] and the ''[[Ingénieur des études et de l'exploitation de l'aviation civile|Ingénieurs des études et de l'exploitation de l'aviation civile]]'').<ref>{{fr}} [http://www.aerobuzz.fr/spip.php?breve1833 Création du Fonds de dotation ENAC]</ref> It has been done in March 2012.<ref>{{fr}} [http://www.alumni.enac.fr/docs/2012161442_120321---enac_alumni_newsletter_mars2012.pdf enac alumni newsletter mars 2012]</ref>
ENAC Alumni is part of the ''[[Conférence des Grandes Écoles]]''.<ref>{{fr}}[http://www.cge.asso.fr/nos-membres/organismes/50-enac-alumni ENAC Alumni]''</ref><ref>{{fr}}[http://jobs.aerobuzz.fr/CURSUS/article/ENAC-Alumni-adhere-a-la-CGE_190_20.html ENAC Alumni adhère à la CGE]</ref>
==Meetings==
ENAC Alumni is a partnership of the yearly meeting [[Airexpo]]<ref>{{fr}} [http://www.cge-news.com/contenus//518/cms_pc/fichier/610/120423143744_lettrenac201204.pdf Ca se passe à l'ENAC]</ref><ref>{{fr}} [http://www.alumni.enac.fr/docs/2012155032_120511---flash-info-1.pdf flash info 1]</ref> and the ''[[Salon du livre aéronautique]]''.<ref>{{fr}} [http://www.aeromorning.com/en/agenda/agenda.php?lejour=2009-11-27&mois=2009/11&categorie=0 l'ENAC fête ses 60ans]</ref>
==Board members==
[[Méziane Idjerouidène]] was one of the board members of the association.<ref>{{fr}} [http://www.alumni.enac.fr/gene/main.php?base=114 Conseil d'administration]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==More reading== * [http://www.alumni.enac.fr/ Official website]
[[Category:French Civil Aviation University]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations of France]] [[Category:1987 establishments]]

revision.text:
'''Idempotence''' is a property that an [[operation]] in [[mathematics]] or [[computer science]] may have. It roughly means that the operation can be carried out again and again without changing the result.
The word idempotence was made by [[Benjamin Pierce]] because he saw the concept when studying algebra.
The meaning is different if we are talking about different kinds of operations. It can also be used to describe [[elements]] than an operation can take:
* For a [[unary operation]] (or [[Function (mathematics)|function]]), that we label ''f'', we say that ''f'' is idempotent if for any ''x'' in the [[domain]] of ''f'' it is true that: ''f(f(x)) = f(x)''. For example, the [[absolute value]]: ''abs(abs(x)) = abs(x)''.
We say that an element ''c'' in the domain of ''f'' is an idempotent element if ''f(f(c)) = f(c)''. This means that ''f'' is idempotent if every element of its domain is an idempotent element.
* For a [[binary operation]], that we label ''*'', we say that ''*'' is idempotent if for any ''x'' which the binary operation can take the following is true: ''x * x = x''.
We say that an element ''c'' which ''*'' can take is an idempotent element for ''*'' if ''c * c = c''. For example, the number ''1'' is an idempotent element for [[multiplication]] because ''1'' times ''1'' is ''1''.
== Examples in the real world ==
If a call button inside an [[elevator]] is pressed then the elevator will go to the floor that is on the button. If it is pressed again then it will do the same thing. This means that the operation of pressing a button to make the elevator change floors is an idempotent operation.
If we mix two pots which have the same liquid in them into a new pot then we will have the same liquid in that pot. If we only care about ''what'' kind of liquid is in the pot (not how much) then mixing liquids is an idempotent binary operation.
The face of a clock looks the same if 12 hours have passed. So for the operation of "letting time pass on a clock" we see that letting 12 hours pass is an idempotent element (this is also true for all [[multiples]] of 12 like 24, 36, 48, ...).
[[Category:Mathematics]] [[Category:Computer science]]

revision.comment: Link to Wikimedia Commons category.
revision.text:
{{Infobox Holiday |holiday_name = Saint David's Day |type = National |longtype = [[National day]] in [[Wales]]. |image = Jesus Chapel St David.jpg |caption = St David |official_name = Dydd Gŵyl Dewi Sant |observedby = [[Wales]], [[Welsh people]], [[Welsh diaspora]] |date = 1 March |celebrations = Children take part in [[eisteddfod]]au. |observances = Parades; wearing Welsh emblems, etc. |relatedto = }}
'''Saint David's Day''' is the feast (celebration) day of [[Saint David]]. He is the [[patron saint]] of [[Wales]]. His feast day falls on the 1st of March each year. The day is celebrated by the people of Wales and people of Welsh background throughout the world. The first day of March was chosen in memory of the death of Saint David. It is believed that he died on that day in 589.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/04640b.htm |title=Catholic Encyclopedia: ''St. David'' |publisher=Newadvent.org |date= |accessdate=2012-03-02}}</ref> The date was declared a national day of celebration within Wales in the 18th century.
Everyone in the National Assembly for Wales voted to make St. David's Day a public holiday in 2000. A poll conducted for Saint David's Day in 2006 found that 87% of people in Wales wanted it to be a [[bank holiday]], with 65% prepared to sacrifice a different bank holiday to ensure this.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/4760362.stm |title=Poll backs St David's Day holiday |author=Guto Thomas |publisher=BBC News |date=1 March 2006 |accessdate=2008-03-01}}</ref> A petition in 2007 to make St. David's Day a bank holiday was rejected by the office of the British Prime Minister, [[Tony Blair]].<ref>[http://www.number-10.gov.uk/output/Page11078.asp Bank-Holiday - epetition reply: ''Prime Minister rejects petition to make St David's Day holiday''], 10 Downing Street.</ref>
Parades are held in Wales on St. David's Day. The largest parade is held in [[Cardiff]]. It is formally attended by either the British Monarch or the [[Prince of Wales]]. Parades are a mixture of [[folklore]] and military parade.<ref>[http://www.stdavidsday.org St. David's Day Parade Cardiff-Gorymdaith Gwyl Dewi Sant Caerdydd] – Official Site for the St David's Day Parade in Cardiff, [[Wales]]</ref> On 1 March 2010, the seventh National St. David's Day Parade took place in Cardiff city centre. Celebrations included concerts, a parade and a food festival featuring all Welsh produce.<ref name="Dewi Sant 11">{{cite news|title=WalesOnline - News - Wales news - Cardiff’s St David’s Day celebrations|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/2010/02/12/cardiff-s-st-david-s-day-celebrations-91466-25818369/accessdate=2010-03-02|publisher=[[Media Wales Ltd]]|date=12 February 2010|work=[[WalesOnline]] website}}</ref><ref name="Dewi Sant 2">{{cite news|title=WalesOnline - CardiffOnline - Cardiff news - Sun shines on St David’s Day parade|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/cardiffonline/cardiff-news/2010/03/02/sun-shines-on-st-david-s-day-parade-91466-25939808/|accessdate=2010-03-02|publisher=[[Media Wales Ltd]]|date=2 March 2010|work=[[WalesOnline]] website}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Commonscat}} [[Category:Wales]]

{{Infobox musical artist |name = Dusty Hill |image = Dusty_hill_finland_2010.jpg |caption = Dusty Hill performing live in July 2010 |image_size = |background = solo_singer |birth_name = Joseph Michael Hill |alias = "Duster", "The Dust" |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1949|05|19|mf=yes}} |origin = [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]], [[Texas]], [[United States|U.S.]] |Family Memebers = Hank Hill |instrument = [[Bass guitar]], [[keyboard instrument|keyboards]], [[Human voice|vocals]], [[guitar]], [[saxophone]], [[bass clarinet]] |genre = [[Hard rock]], [[blues rock]], [[Rock music|rock]] |occupation = [[bassist]], [[singer-songwriter]] |years_active = 1966–present |label = [[Rhino Entertainment|Rhino/WEA]], [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]], [[London Records|London]] |associated_acts = [[ZZ Top]], [[Willy & the Wolves]], [[Freddie King]], [[The Warlocks]], [[The Cellar Dwellers]], [[American Blues]] |website = |current_members = |past_members = |notable_instruments = [[Fender Telecaster Bass|Vintage Fender Telecaster Bass]]
[[Fender Precision Bass|Fender Precision]]
[[Dean Guitars|Dean Z Bass]] }} '''Joseph Michael "Dusty" Hill''' (born May 19, 1949) is an [[United States|American]] musician and co-vocalist for the rock band ''[[ZZ Top]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/zz-top-p5923|title=ZZ Top|last=Koda|first=Cub|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=17 August 2011}}. He had also made many voice guest appearance such as in ''[[King of the Hill]]'' and has been in movies such as ''[[Back to the Future III]]''. Hill was born on May 19, 1949 in Dallas, Texas. He studied at [[Woodrow Wilson High School]]. Hill has been married to Charleen McCrory since 2002. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Other websites== {{Commons category}} * {{IMDb name|0384212}} {{US-bio-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hill, Dusty}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American rock musicians]] [[Category:People from Dallas, Texas]] [[Category:Musicians from Texas]]

Gibbons, The Reverend Willy G., BFG | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1949|12|16}}
[[Houston, Texas]], United States | origin = | instrument = Guitar, vocals, harmonica, bass | genre = [[Hard rock]], [[blues rock]], [[rock music|rock]], [[blues]] | occupation = Musician, songwriter, actor | years_active = 1967–present | Labels = [[London Records|London]], [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]], [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[American Recordings|American]] | associated_acts = [[ZZ Top]], [[Moving Sidewalks]], [[Brooks & Dunn]], [[Roky Erickson]], [[Nickelback]], [[Queens of the Stone Age]], [[DJ Screw]], [[Screwed-up Click]] | website = [http://www.billygibbons.com/ The Official Website of Billy F Gibbons] | current_members = | past_members = | notable_instruments = [[Pearly Gates (guitar)|Pearly Gates]] (1959 Gibson Les Paul maple sunburst)
[[Gretsch Jupiter Thunderbird]]
[[Gibson Les Paul]]
[[Gibson Explorer]] }} '''William Frederick "Billy" Gibbons''' (born December 16, 1949) is an [[United States|American]] musician, actor, and car customizer. He is known for inventing the [[Gibson Les Paul]] (along with [[Les Paul]]) and for being in the rock band ''[[ZZ Top]]''. Gibbons was born on December 16, 1949 in Houston, Texas. He has been married to Gilligan Stillwater since 2005. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Other websites== {{Commons category}} * {{IMDb name|0316531}} *[http://www.billygibbons.com/ Official Billy Gibbons website] *[http://www.zztop.com/ ZZ Top Official website] {{US-bio-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gibbons, Billy}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American rock guitarists]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Houston, Texas]] [[Category:Actors from Houston, Texas]]

revision.comment: /* External links */ to other websites
revision.text:
{{Infobox prepared food | name = Cawl | image = [[File:Cawl Cymreig.jpg|250px]] | caption = Cawl with unthickened stock | alternate_name = | country = [[Wales]] | region = Southwest | creator = | course = First and/or second | type = [[Soup]]
[[Stew]] | served = Hot | main_ingredient = [[Potato]]es, [[rutabaga]]s, [[carrot]]s, [[leek]]s, [[meat]] (lamb, mutton, beef, bacon) | variations = | calories = | other = }} '''Cawl''' is a [[Wales|Welsh]] dish. It was traditionally eaten during the winter months in the south-west of [[Wales]].Davies, (2008) p.130 Today the word is often used to refer to a dish containing [[lamb]] and [[leek]]s, but historically it was made with either salted [[bacon]] or [[beef]], [[potato]]es, [[carrot]]s and other vegetables. Cawl is widely considered to be the national dish of Wales.{{cite web|last=Staff|title=Children celebrate St David's Day with traditional cawl |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/southwestwales/hi/people_and_places/newsid_8550000/8550170.stm|publisher=BBC News |date=5 March 2010|accessdate=13 March 2012}} The meat in the dish was normally cut into medium-sized pieces and boiled with the vegetables in water. The stock was thickened with either [[oatmeal]] or [[flour]]. It was then served, without the meat or vegetables, as a first course. The vegetables and slices of the meat would then be served as a second course. Cawl served as a single course is today the most popular way to serve the dish. Cawl is similar to ''lobsgows'', cawl's north Wales equivalent. ''Lobsgows'' differs in that the meat and vegetables are cut into smaller pieces. The stock is not thickened. "Cawl cennin", or leek cawl, can be made without meat but using meat stock. In some areas cawl is often served with bread and cheese. These are served separately on a plate. The dish was traditionally cooked in an iron pot or cauldron over the fire.{{cite web|last=Staff|title=Captain Alfie laps up cawl crawl |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_west/4749382.stm |publisher=BBC News |date=26 February 2006| accessdate=13 March 2012}} It was eaten with wooden spoons.Freeman (1980) p.82 The word ''cawl'' in [[Welsh language|Welsh]] is first recorded in the 14th century, and is thought to come from the [[Latin]] ''{{lang|la|caulis}}'', meaning the stalk of a plant, a [[cabbage]] stalk or a cabbage. In Welsh, ''{{lang|cy|gwneud cawl o [rywbeth]}}'' ("make a cawl of [something]") means to mess something up. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |editor1-first=John |editor1-last=Davies|editor1-link=John Davies (historian)|editor2-first=Nigel |editor2-last=Jenkins | editor2-link=Nigel Jenkins| editor3-first=Baines |editor3-last=Menna|editor4-first=Peredur I. |editor4-last=Lynch|title=The Welsh Academy Encyclopaedia of Wales |year=2008 |publisher=University of Wales Press |location=Cardiff |isbn=978-0-7083-1953-6}} * {{cite book |last=Freeman |first=Bobby |title=First Catch Your Peacock, a book of Welsh food |year=1980 |publisher=Image Imprint |location=Griffithstown, Gwent |isbn=0-9507254-1-2}} ==Other websites== ;Recipes *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/mid/sites/food/pages/cawlcennin.shtml BBC Mid Wales article and recipe for Cawl Cennin] *[http://www.welshholidaycottages.com/food/welsh-cawl.htm Recipe for Cawl Cymreig] [[Category:Wales]] [[Category:Foods]]
